clean_story:
"Building blocks. Nature’s LEGO. "

"Molecular self-assembly" means tiny parts—like atoms or molecules—snapping together on their own, no instructions needed.

Think of snowflakes forming in clouds. No one arranges the water molecules—they just fit perfectly when it’s cold.

Scientists copy this trick. DNA strands, for example, can be programmed to fold into nanoscale shapes—like a box that delivers medicine only to sick cells.

Or soap bubbles in water: Their molecules automatically line up, tail-to-tail, to trap dirt. No stirring. No commands.
The rules are simple: Shape, charge, and environment decide how pieces lock together—like magnets finding their match.

One real-world use? Solar panels that repair themselves when cracked, because their molecules reassemble.

Three related subjects are nanotechnology basics, crystal growth patterns, and biomimicry in engineering.
